text:
It's OK to make jokes about neurodiveristy.

Neurodiversity has this image where it's all very serious and sensible but NDs are some of the funniest people I've ever met - and a frequent source of humour is our own conditions.

Humour makes it easier to engage with people too.

text:
Hating small talk is a trait of autism. 

And other forms of neurodiversity, including a segment of those of us with ADHD. 

And introverts. 

But you know what we do like? BIG talk. Talk about things that MATTER. 

Things that excite us. 

Bring me the BIG talk. https://t.co/5BDKvk0LdS

text: @Melinda_McGraw @Acyn Evil and a type of neurodiversity are not synonymous.  Sociopathy is a diagnosable and manageable neurological arrangement. text:
signs you have ADHD or AUTISM: 

1. there aren’t neat boxes you can check off
2. the majority of the discourse on neurodiversity is derived from analysis conducted by and academic texts written by white men, disregarding complexities in behavior in queer ppl, women & ppl of color

text: @JellyCraven From my perspective, neurodiverse/neurodiversity mean the diversity of neurologies that exist. Neurodivergent is a neurology that “significantly diverges from the norm.” Autism is one form of ND. These terms all imply pathology. “Neurospicy” seems outside the pathology framework.

text:
@buttonslives I see this in D&I initiatives in the workplace too. 

Neurodiversity originally came about to refute the idea of 'normal' and show how similar we are: 'we're all on the same spectrum'. Now its only used to demonstrate and 'celebrate' what can be very painful differences.

text:
The field of adult autistic care is woefully under-resourced.

It’s really hard to find neurodiversity-affirming care, or services that‘ve been informed by autistic perspectives. And our hope is to change that. 

We want anyone who is willing to learn to have a chance to do so…

text:
When I was young nobody talked about dyspraxia. I felt so weird - socially and physically awkward, found things like maths, drawing, sports so difficult and I didn’t know why. 
Today’s approach to #neurodiversity is so great. Nothing wrong with seeing the world a bit differently!

text:
Differences are neutral. Diversity is valuable. 

For example, neurotype differences (being neurotypical or neurodivergent) are not good or bad. They are value-neutral. And neurodiversity adds value to the world, just as all diversity does.

@laurenancona @bibicosplays Some people (often the most boring, most privileged) see neurodiversity as a threat. We see the world as it could be, and that's scary.

Don't let them.

Being different is a strength.

text:
People really, really don’t understand neurodiversity. That includes critics, but also a lot of self-professed proponents.

It’s not about whether autism is a superpower, or a disease. It’s a challenge to the entire concept of classifying body-minds as “normal” or “pathological.”

text:
The unemployment rate for neurodivergent workers is 8x HIGHER than those without a disability. 

Even worse - 85% of autistic adults are underemployed or unemployed.

We need to do better and hold our employers accountable for prioritizing neurodiversity inclusion.

text:
@AuthorConfusion Neurodiversity is a label for the fact that multiple neurotypes exist.

Neurodivergence is the quality of being of a minority or marginalized neurotype.

text:
Therapy today felt truly neurodiversity-affirming. My therapist said:

“You relive social events more often than most people - it helps you process. It’s not causing distress, so there’s no need to work on it. No need to change for the sake of being ‘normal’”👏🏼
#ActuallyAutistic

text:
Use of these words over time

Depression, spiked around the 1950's, began more so in the 1800's.

text:

2. Avoid labeling:

Neurodiversity can’t be shoved into a label or a box–it’s more of a spectrum of needs, hence the name.

So, instead of jumping to conclusions on how best to care for someone’s needs, listen, and take note of their preferences.

text:
Any other definition is scientifically inaccurate. 

#autism is genetic and it can never be fixed or cured without delving into the world of eugenics.
Hans Asperger, who inspired the now defunct term, was part of this. It's basically genocide. Cleanse the world of #Neurodiversity

text: What is the goal of the neurodiversity movement? Put simply. Most special ed focuses on brokenness of NDs and employs various methods to fix us. Neurodiversity focuses on the brokenness of the system that fails to accommodate our support needs. We are not broken; the system is.
